text: Came here with my friends during the holidays to catch up on a lovely winter day.   I loved entering this cafe because of all the light that made it feel so airy (is that a word?). There were a few tables and seating by the window with lovely seats. I took a delicious chai latte with a great chocolate, which was unfortunately not warm - but it still was great. I even tried the green juice because it sounded delectable and I was pretty much right! This place was perfect for us because we got to talk and read tarot cards (even though there were some people looking at us quite weirdly).   The only thing that bothered me a bit was the lack of space, but other than that, it was perfect!

Welcoming, friendly staff in a crisp, airy atmosphere seconds away from Plaza St-Hubert. I drink a lot of decaf coffee and have often had issues with less flavourful decaf - I now swear by Cafellini's as it is pleasantly well-balanced and their specialty drinks are always perfectly crafted.

Cefellini opened yesterday, so this is a very early review based on limited experience and should be taken as such!  That said, those of you familiar with the old Café Volâne with the mismatched interior, almost-residential kitchen set up--well, forget all about that.  Cafellini has remodelled this teeny spot--inside and out--to a modern day coffee spot with everything you'd expect from a new café in a budding neighbourhood: clean, slick, minimalist design, some eiffel chairs, and a long communal table (don't worry, there are a few other 2-person tables as well). The most colourful thing in here is their coffee bags, which are quite lovely if I do say so myself.  My coffee was flavourful and bold, but not bitter at all. I tried one of their savoury scones (bacon and cheese) and it was also pretty good.   In terms of food, there were few options: scones, cookies and yoghurt parfaits, so from what I can tell, the lunch offerings from the old place are a thing of the past. No doubt we will see some adjustments to the menu in the coming weeks, or maybe not.   Conveniently located across from Beaubien Metro, I recommend you grab your coffee here if you're headed underground or are passing by.

Beau café, assez grand ! La déco est bien chaleureuse, tout comme les employés ! Je n'ai pas été déçue par la nourriture non plus. J'aime la petite touche un peu plus "spicy" qu'ils ajoutent à certains aliments plus classiques (à découvrir par exemple le biscuit genre choco-piment). Bref, c'est un bel endroit où s'installer pour travailler de longues heures !!

Cafellini is a beautiful minimalist dream with a fair amount of seating and lovely eiffel chairs. The coffee is great and the location is perfect for grabbing a cub before going into the Beaubien metro station.  I wrote a more detailed review with photos on my blog which you can check out here: http://www.leblogsansnom.com/blog/2016/2/21/caffeine-fix-cafellini
I found is coffee shop rather pleasing. They have a no wifi policy which is understandable. The coffee itself was tasty and will be going back.

Petit café de quartier, à 2 pas du métro Beaubien, pratique en hiver quand on ne veut pas marcher trop longtemps à l'extérieur pour se rendre à un café! Il n'y a pas beaucoup de places (peut accueillir environ 15 personnes max je pense), mais je ne l'ai jamais vu plein à craquer, donc généralement si vous etes seul(e) ou à 2, vous trouverez une place!  Wifi gratuit Vous pouvez y aller pour chiller, surfer sur le net, boire du bon café,.. Staff très sympa Les thés sont des sachets de Kusmi Tea (environ 12 sortes) Bons rapports qualité/prix en général pour ce que j'ai pu voir et tester A essayer!
Les employés sont super accueillants et chaleureux et le meilleur chai latté que j'ai goûté se retrouve là! Un peu petit comme espace mais super bien situé à quelques pas du métro Beaubien.

Came here after shopping for beers on saint-Hubert. The coffee shop looked beautiful from the outside so I entered the place and grabbed a cappuccino. While the staff were extremely friendly, prompt and efficient, the criticism that were laid out in the other reviews are sadly true. The coffee, while better than the likes at starbucks or second cup, was not as good as other third wave coffee shops in the area, and the milk based drinks were not made with the same level of skills.

Petit café vraiment cute, bien situé devant le métro Beaubien! Belle déco, café plutôt bien, super bon scones! J'ai développé une folie des scones, et ils en offrent de plusieurs sortes, salés ou sucrés. Ceux aux bleuets sont juste malades... C'est pas l'endroit le plus cozy pour travailler, mais je trippe sur sa déco minimaliste.

J'ai hésité avant de faire cette review.  D'abord parce que je venais de manger un bonbon au gingembre juste avant de goûter le café, puis parce que je revenais du San Simeon et je ne pensais pas trouver mieux au Cafellini.   Service impeccable. Accueil chaleureux et barista attentionnée. L'endroit est bien: c'est éclairé, coloré, on peut s'asseoir sur les bancs ou aux tables. Même si c'est petit, on ne se sent pas étouffé.   Mais le café... non. J'ai VRAIMENT hésité à m'avouer que c'était mauvais, à cause du bonbon au gingembre. Mais après trente minutes avec le goût de brûlé qui reste dans la bouche... non. Vraiment pas. Et ça me désole parce que c'est un bel endroit et j'ai adoré la barista. Mais c'était tellement pas succulent que je n'ai pas osé en parler. Des fois, un petit détail peut faire une différence, mais là, c'était trop pour demander quoi que ce soit. Je ne sais pas ce qui clochait, mais je passerai mon tour la prochaine fois, malheureusement.

When your Americano tastes like a drip, you earn a ho hum review. The space is bright, good amount of seating, standing bar by the windows for premium people watching. But when it comes to the brew game, it's game over. Plus the cookies are wrapped in plastic and so much tape you almost need a box cutter. But, as they say, the only way is up & Cafellini can reach the sky. If fueled by better coffee, of course.
A cross between the 50s and the future. If the Jetsons visited a café it would be here. I had a yummy macchiato and gigantic cookie. Their store has a unique brand that is worth visiting.

Bon petit café dans le quartier, en plus ils ouvrent tot donc parfait avant d'aller au boulot. En arrivant juste à l'ouverture je pense que je les ai un peu surpris. En tout cas mon petit latte était bon. Ce n'est pas tres grand donc pas forcement le mieux pour travailler.
J'ai pris un café cortado, c'était bon :) le croissant était excellent! Et oui c'est petit mais c'est agréable quand même. J'y retourne!
Great coffee shop, the coffee is exceptional (top 5 in Montreal's greater area). The owner was very kind and gave an impeccable service! A must-visit coffee shop for people around the area!

J'avais besoin de caféine. J'allais ramassé un colis au Jean Coutu juste à côté. C'est dans un endroit un peu ordinaire sur Beaubien, mais l'endroit "ressort" et parait bien. Pas très grand, c'est un repère d'étudiants ou jeunes travailleurs qui vont là pour étudier, boire un café.   Le café n'est pas donné mais raisonnable avec les prix des cafés avoisinants. Un beau café de quartier!

I went to Cafellini during a special price event: 1-2-3$ for any coffee of small-medium-big size, it was really nice! I tried their latte and it was so good. The café is right next to Beaubien station, and very close to another popular cafe called Pista. It is a very bright cafe with a lot of panoramic windows. It is quite crowded in the weekend and people usually have to take-out when it's peak hours in the afternoon. I love studying at this cafe and would recommend it!

J'avais entendu parler de leur latté à la citrouille vegan (denrée rare!). J'ai commandé avec lait d'amandes et j'ai a-do-ré. C'était le meilleur café que j'ai bu depuis longtemps (et j'ai moi-même été barista pendant des années, je sais de quoi je parle). J'ai entendu dire que leur lait d'amandes était fait maison, ce qui peut expliquer pourquoi il était si crémeux! J'allais souvent au café Volâne qui occupait ce local autrefois, et on a encore davantage gagné en qualité! Bravo Cafellini, vous méritez votre bonne réputation.

I'm of two hearts.  In the first, I couldn't be more proud of an institution from my hometown opening their first Montreal location. In the other, I can't deny the socio-political dynamics of coffee between Montreal and tiny Saint-Bruno are worlds apart. So despite encouraging you, full-stop, to visit this shop, I also know I'd just as soon recommend you visit Dispatch, Cafe Falco, Névé, or the many other stops within a 2km radius. Places where the coffee is simply better.  Setting coffee aside for a moment, Cafellini's city transplant is impressive. I'm not usually that impressed by storefronts but their's stands out: I love the stark black on white lettering and the faux wood moulding detailing. Nothing else like it comes to mind in the St-Hubert Plaza. (There's gentrification flag-waving to be made, but Yelp doesn't quite seem the place to do it.) The decor manages to both expand on the slow rebranding that's been taking place at the Saint-Bruno location and find its own distinct voice. If 3rd wave coffee aesthetics here tend to moonlight as industrial showrooms for up-cycled furniture, Cafellini sports the customized combination of high end Ikea white, Pantone colours, and birch veneered surfaces. You won't ever find me complaining about a place that's flush in daylight and clean lines.  Onto the more pressing parts.   If I'm torn about the beverages, here's why. I think owning a successful coffee shop in a tiny suburb of the South Shore has isolated Cafellini from being a full participant in that culture, and perhaps crucially, isolated it from the experience the vibrant coffee market Montreal affords.   Here's isolation at work: Despite being over a decade old, Cafellini's coffee over that time has hardly changed. To my taste, their only roaster (Montreal based indie roasters Barista) compares poorly to any of the B.C. (49th Parallel/Bow & Arrows) or Ontario (Detour) products you can find here, let alone any staple U.S. roaster. So even if the coffee drinks are prepared to spec, I can't remember being excited, surprised, or particularly pleased from a Cafellini coffee. But being from a suburb where you're fighting for attention against Second Cup and Tim's, I suspect few clients have ever complained, suggested an alternative, or purely off-the-cuff opened up a dialogue about different coffee roasts to Cafellini staff in the way I suspect baristas across the city are accosted about these matters on a daily basis.   Worse, my sense is that the outright friendly and dedicated staff--across both locations--have never been comparatively passionate and serious about coffee. But it's a chicken and egg problem I don't lay at Cafellini's feet. No one from the city who wants to dedicate themselves to coffee craft is going to travel to Saint-Bruno given the plentiful options at home. And the local student body comprising the majority of the Cafellini staff over the years is a small pool from which to produce year after year classes of passionate baristas. And this specially given most of them have never known better coffee than Cafellini itself. An absence of clients and staff of the types that make small food cultures thrive, Saint-Bruno Cafellini has sadly become staid coffee-wise.   This is what makes me reticent to suggest the Beaubien location. My own hometown nostalgia is a siren song that'll drags me through its door, but I can't find the same frequency for your ears.
